div.p: 1. V. Wednesday.

Cold Night and Morning—so finger pinching that it robs me of my best writing time— Young Franzoni was here, with another young man named Kelly, both printers, and in want of employment— Kelly said that the hard times affected the printing business very much; the merchants having far less printing work to be done than when business was so prosperous— He said he expected to be employed in Gales and Seaton’s Office in December— I told Franzoni that I knew not of any public office vacant to which I could recommend him; but that if an opportunity should present itself by which I could serve him I would do it with pleasure— Simon Willard the Clock maker came, and said he was here to put up a Clock which he had made for the Supreme Court of the United States, and thought he must call to see me, and remind me of that old Clock, the first that he ever made, and which when I was President was one of the first things in the world that I remembered— I told him it was yet standing in the chamber entry of my house at Quincy, and was now the best time piece I ever knew, not excepting a pocket Chronometer made for me by French the first Chronometer maker in the world, which I took from my pocket and shewed him.— That when at Quincy, I regularly wound up the Clock every Sunday Morning; but that it now wanted repair—a new suspension of the weights; and when he got home, I wished he would go out and repair it— He said he would— He is now 85 years old and his name is on the face of the Clock, dated Lexington 1774— He shewed me a Letter from Dr. Waterhouse, about of his own age, dated 22. October, cautioning him against self-exposure at his time of life, on this journey— I was detained till Noon before I could go, for a second sitting to Mrs Towle, who will make a hideous object of me— The third sitting is to be this day week— Thence I went to the Congress library, and took out the volume of Bacon’s Essays— I examined the catalogue of Actaeon’s hounds in Banier’s French translation of the Metamorphoses—two folio volumes with beautiful figures by Picart— I examined the Catalogue also in the Delphin Edition. The Commentator gives the significancy of the Greek names of the dogs, but says that the Post has blundered in making them too long— That sportsmen always give their dogs short names— Generally of one syllable— This is good criticism; but applies only to a part of Ovid’s dogs. I suppose the Catalogue is imitated from the names of the frogs and mice in Homer’s Batrachomuomachia— Nathan Allen, the husband of the woman and children sold last week, came this evening with the subscription paper, to pay Birch for them— They are now in the Jail waiting for this money to be raised to have them delivered over to the Husband and father— I subscribed fifty dollars to be paid if the sum be made up to complete the purchase— I enquired of Allen, apparently an active, but very ignorant man, how Dorcas came to be the property of Rezin Orme; he said some people thought she was not— She had originally belonged to a woman in Baltimore named Emery, who married Gideon Davis. on her death bed she made Davis promise that he would give Dorcas her freedom—but Davis never did— He married a second wife namedbelonging to
Georgetown— Davis himself died without emancipating Dorcas and his widow—married Rezin Orme—who sold her and her four children— Dorcas is subject to epileptic fits very violent after which she is sick ten or twelve days— She has been repeatedly sold and turned back on account of these fits, and often turned upon her husband’s hands to be maintained and doctored at his charge, because her owners would not incur the expence— The eldest of the surviving girls is 12 years old, and named Maria—the youngest 9. He says he shall easily find a place for Maria, who is a smart child— It is very doubtful whether I have not imprudently engaged myself in this matter, which I must pursue further— The emancipation of the woman and children is not yet secured— I finished the draught of my Speech of 14. October—but was obliged to close the Evening soon after nine.
2. V. Thursday.

I had postponed until yesterday the making of a fire in the dining room, and began with the 1st. of November— This may be considered as the Law of the climate at this place— Casual fires, chiefly morning and evening, a few days in October— Steady fires from the first of November.— April in the Spring corresponds with October in Autumn I had a morning visit from Mr Thomas Munroe, an old co-temporary, whom I have known upwards of 30 years, and who for 25 of them was Postmaster, of this city. The late President Jackson dismissed him, and he has fallen into hypocondriac habits for want of occupation— He raised a family of five or six children two of whom he has lost in an afflictive manner— His eldest son of a venturous and romantic disposition, went at the age of 19 or 20 to Russia and entered the service of the Emperor Alexander. He was treated there very courteously, obtained a Lieutenant’s Commission in the army, and afterwards an appointment as Aid de Camp of the Grand-duke Constantine— He served in the War against Turkey but four or five years since took a typhus fever, from which he partially recovered, but lingered a long five or six months and died.— An amiable daughter married to a young man of the Ramsey family, but living in her fathers house, two years ago last Spring, died of a puerperal fever leaving an infant to his care. Mrs Monroe was at the time for months after dangerously ill and is yet in infirm health— These afflictions have broken him down, and he is suffering as he says from what is commonly called blue devils— He could not describe the symptoms of his complaint; but asked me whether I had ever experienced the like; and whether I could prescribe a remedy for his disease— I told him that I knew what it was that I had occasionally been afflicted with it; always when I had nothing to do—never at any other time— Intense occupation was a never failing cure, and it was therefore principle and habit with me, to keep myself always busy—with serious affairs as much as possible— With trifles, for exercise, variety and relaxation— As to a remedy for him I
asked him if he had tried riding on horseback? sometimes, and with good effect— Had he visited the watering places? Yes—for many years in succession—but he was obliged now to economize, and could not afford the expence? Had he sought cheerful company? he could not endure company, and was often annoyed even by visitors in his family— I told him my materia medica was exhausted—exercise, active exercise—open air, temperance, cheerful company and above all constant employment of body or mind were all the remedies I knew for the blue devils— He said that was precisely what his doctors had told him, and what he fully believed to be true— He said his case was not so bad as that of John C. Herbert of Prince George’s County—many years a member of Congress—formerly a warm friend of my administration, but since an equally warm Jackson man— He has taken it into his head that he is starving to death with want, and has actually been seen naked in the woods— He thinks it above all hard, that General Jackson never gave him an Office— A very respectable man, monomaniac, for fear of poverty— I compassionate the case of Mr Munroe— Wretchedness in old age, (68) from misfortunes, and a lack of fortitude to bear them— Want of occupation, and of energy to make it for himself— I called at Mr Dyer’s auction room—to enquire about Dorcas Allen and her children— Dyer had been misinformed that they would be liberated by the giving of a note to a man who would lend Allen the money, which Mr Key was to endorse— He said the woman and children were not at the Jail, and that Mr Key had gone to Mrs Orme, in her sick chamber, she having been lately confined; and had frightened her so by threatening her with the Law that it was not expected she would live— He pronounced a panegyric upon Orme, who he said was one of the best and most respectable men in the world— And as to the Slaves, he had a right to sell them—they were his property— I asked him by what authority he had sold them— He said by Mr Birch’s—that he had not asked him for any proof that they were his—he had trusted to his word— I said I understood they were not Orme’s property— He said they were his by his wife— I said I had heard they were not his wife’s— Well, he said he had heard so too— They were really part of Gideon Davis’s Estate— He died insolvent, and they belonged to his creditors, and if he was one of them he would claim them as such— Here then is another danger to which these unhappy beings are subjected— If their freedom from Birch’s sale should be purchased, they might still be reclaimed by Davis’s creditors. I went to the Office of the National Intelligencer, and told Mr Seaton that I expected to bring him the Manuscript of my Speech to-morrow— He said he should not be at the Office on Saturday. While I was there, William Cost Johnson and Matthew St Clair Clarke came in— I was telling Seaton that I had called at the Office last Thursday at dusk, and he was not there, and of Mr Fowler’s surprize at meeting me walking in the rain— Clarke said he would tell me what Stackelberg had once said of me when I was president— He said [“]Mr Adams is a Shentleman— When I meet him walking in the morning shust after taylight, when I am going home from a place where perhaps I ought not to have peen, he passes by and tont see me—put if I jouce to meet him in the mittle of the tay, he holds out his hant and says Ha! Baron, hour to ye too— That’s a man who knows when he should see a shentleman, and when he should not.”— Poor Stackelberg—a brave, honest kind hearted, dissolute man, ruined by dissipated habits and gambling.— He exposed his life
life together with my dear departed son John, day and night here, in tending the sick here at the hospital, at the time of the Cholera in 1832. and he finally went away leaving his creditors in the lurch, among whom was Kervand, for his board and lodging— Evening call at W. S. Smith’s but they were not at home.
3. V. Friday.

I received a distressing Letter from my Son, directed to me at Baltimore with directions to forward it to me here if I should not be there. It was written partly last Sunday evening, when he says his mother was ready to leave home upon her journey to come here, but there was a prospect of a storm which might delay her departure; and partly Monday Morning when he says she was less well, and leaves it doubtful what day she would come on. I fear she was very ill.— The discomposure occasioned by this intelligence disabled me from completing the manuscript of my Speech by adjustment of it to the Reporter’s Notes— I took it however to the Intelligencer Office, thinking that the first part of it might be printed on Monday Morning, and was in a sufficient state of preparation. Seaton had told me, that they must divide it into two of the daily papers, to have it all in the Country paper— Seaton was not at the Office— I went to the Office of the Franklin Insurance Company and found Mr Bradley— He had the Policy, on Mary’s House, where we live corner of I. and 16th. Streets. Square 185 ready—4000 dollars for one year from the 1st. of this Month—for which I paid 12 dollars and 1. for the policy— I took the Policy and gave Mr Bradley a check on the Bank of Washington for the money— I leave my own houses in the city yet uninsured, but could not suffer Mary’s longer to remain so— Mr Bradley shewed me the Report ready to be made to the board of Directors, recommending a dividend of 8 per Cent for the last half year—2 per cent less than several of the preceding dividends, on account of the fire which destroyed Washington’s House and shop last June—upon which they had two policys—one for 10000 dollars and one for 3000—they paid the smallest as a total loss,—and compounded for the largest by paying 8000— There were very strong suspicions that the fire was kindled for the insurance; but no competent proof— Mr Bradley shewed me also a blank policy of the Manhattan company variant somewhat from that now used by the Franklin Company and which he said the Directors of the Franklin Company thought of adopting— It engages the company only to the amount of the proved interest of the assured— I returned to the Intelligencer Office, and Mr Seaton, soon afterwards came in— We arranged the manuscript of my Speech, with the Reporter’s Notes so that half of it may be printed on Monday—but on returning home I found that I had not taken with me this morning my tabular Statement, the most important part of the Speech— I took it to the Intelligencer Office immediately after dinner, and found Seaton still there. I took back with me my Manuscript and the part of the Reporter’s Notes, still to be adjusted to it, and was engaged the whole evening in splicing them together but did not finish— I received an invitation from Mrs Forsyth to a sociable party to-morrow evening.
4. V:15. Saturday.

Mr Lewis Johnson was here this morning, and brought a Letter to Mr John Otis of West Barnstable which he asked me to read and to forward— It notified him that Mr David A. Hall had been employed, expressly to go to Massachusetts, and collect the testimony, necessary to establish the claim of the late William Otis, upon the Government; that Mr Hall had
had left the City upon his mission, and would probably see Mr Otis himself, whom Mr Johnson very earnestly invites to come also here— He told me, it was Mr Key’s opinion, that if they could obtain the desired testimony—they would recover as much as twenty thousand dollars of the claiming without needing to petition Congress, though for the remainder a new petition would be necessary. I was again occupied almost the whole morning, in adjusting together my manuscript, and the Reporter’s Notes, of my Speech of 14. October; with a note, on the proceedings of the House of Representatives at the close of the Session Monday the 16th till a boy brought me a note from the Intelligencer Office, calling for the manuscript. I took it to the Office myself. Seaton was not there; but I explained to Mr Barnard the foreman, the manner in which the reporters notes, were to be adjusted to my manuscript, and I requested him to publish the Bill as it passed, after my speech and note with the words upon which I commented in Italics, and with the amendment of the Senate dove-tailed into the middle of the second Session, inserted between brackets and also in Italics, which he promised to do.— To morrow at Noon I am to be furnished with the proof of the part of the Speech to be published on Monday, including the tabular Statement— I called also at Niles’s Register Office— He had promised to publish the whole Speech; which I requested him to do in the Register of next Saturday—which he said he would or in a Supplement— I then went to the Capitol, and in the Congress Library spent a couple of hours in examining the Athenian Letters, by the brothers Philip and Charles Yorke and others in 1741— I found them so deeply interesting that I lamented not having time to read them; but I could not find what I wanted concerning Solon— Mr Meehan shewed me a list of new books, just received from London, and not yet opened; among them was Bulwer’s Athens; which I bespoke, as soon as it should be unpacked— In the Evening, I called Mr W. S. Smith’s, and then attended the sociable party to which I had been invited by Mrs Forsyth— President Van-Buren, and his son Martin were there—Mr. Martini, Chargé d’Affaires from Belgium—Mr Cavalcanti d’Albuquerque the Chargé d’Affaires from Brazil, with his lately married wife, and her Sister Miss Okey, of New-York Miss Hughes, who Mrs Meigs, Mrs Forsyth’s mother told me was engaged to Mr Tacon—Two Miss Macomb’s; Major Macomb and the General’s Son.— Mr Forsyth’s children, six or seven daughters and one boy about twelve years old— Mrs Meigs told me that Mrs Madison had engaged to be there; but had sent this evening an excuse; her eyes being unable to bear the light— The Conversation was pleasant, easy, and truly sociable— Mrs Albuquerque, played on the Piano, to the singing of her Sister, Italian Opera Music— Miss Hughes sung and played Italian and French Music—all very good— Mr Van Buren was as usual courteous to all, and particularly to me— He asked me, as he constantly does several questions about my Son—always the same questions— And when he came away, invited me to take a seat with him in his Carriage, which I did, and he took me home, between 10 and 11. His Son Martin was with
with him— As I left the Carriage, he said he should be always happy to see me, which I took as an invitation, and answered that I should certainly call to see him very soon— I propose to call, a day or two after my speech shall have been published.
5. IV:30. Sunday.

I went this morning to the Presbyterian Church, with out recollecting that it was their communion day. Dr Laurie and Mr Fowler were both in the pulpit, but the service had not begun— The weather was at Summer heat, and fires had been made in the stoves—one of which is so near to my pew that I could not endure it.— The Presbyterian Communion service is very long, and they exclude from it all who dissent from their creed concerning the Trinity and the atonement— They also take exception to a stranger’s leaving the Church between the Sermon, and the administration of the communion— So I thought best to leave it before the service began— I went to the Unitarian Church, where I found judge Cranch, in the seat under the pulpit reading prayers, and afterwards a Sermon from Romans 13.11.— [“]And that, knowing the time, that now it is high time to awake out of sleep”—without the remainder of the verse. As they have no regular Pastor, they have adopted the forms of prayer used at the Stone Chapel in Boston— Of which there were small pamphlets in the pews— The judge’s discourse was short and well written— He considered Sin, as the sleep of the Soul, and pursued the figure as far as it would go— Mrs Cranch, and Mr James Greenleaf were there. I then went to the Office of the National Intelligencer, and revised the proof slips of five columns of my Speech of the evening of 14. October— I have called it a Speech on Nouns, Pronouns, Verbs and Adverbs, with reference to one of Cambreleng’s rude interruptions, saying that he could not pass the Night in discussing Nouns and Pronouns, Verbs and Adverbs with the Gentleman from Massachusetts.— Seaton is afraid of this caption, and says he must insert a Note to say it is not of their invention, to which I readily agreed— I use it to draw attention to the Speech, the details of which are tediously dry, with a continual reference to figures.— I have hopes that the oddity of the title will excite curiosity to read; and that it will also draw public attention to the wretchedly loose manner in which the acts of Congress are drawn up.— This is one of the worst that ever appeared on the Statute Book— Seaton’s alarm however is not without foundation, and the experiment is hazardous— He said the remainder of the Speech was all in type; and the proof would be ready for my revisal, to-morrow at Noon— After dinner I attended at St. John’s Church, and heard Mr Hawley read prayers for the 24th Sunday after Trinity, and preach from Isaiah 11.2. “And the Spirit of the Lord shall rest upon him, the spirit of wisdom and understanding, the spirit of counsel and might, the spirit of knowledge, and of the fear of the Lord. 3 And shall make him of quick Understanding in the fear of the Lord: and he shall not judge after the sight of his eyes, neither reprove after the hearing of his ears.”— The text was long, but the discourse was short.— In the evening I spent half
half an hour at Mr W. S. Smith’s— Mrs Hanson came in while I was there with her Son, a boy of 12 or 13. Mr Smith walked home with me. Mr G. C. Verplanck of New-York had written to me requesting introductory Letters for his brother Dr William Walton Verplanck, to some persons in the Republic of Colombia— Dr Verplanck is going to South America for health and scientific researches— I wrote three Letters of introduction to Franklin Litchfield, Consul of the U.S at Puerto-Cabello—J. M. Macpherson, Consul at Carthagena, and Charles Savage, Consul at Guatemala, the only persons in that Country with whom I have acquaintance; and I enclosed them to Mr Verplanck— Began a Letter to A. H. Everett but was soon obliged to desist and seek my bed— Deep anxiety for my family.
6. IV:15. Monday

Received a Letter from my Son; dated last Thursday, at Boston— My wife has been detained by illness, so severe that on Monday last, the day on which she had intended to leave Quincy, Charles says he decided to send for Dr Holbrook— On Tuesday she was so much better, that Charles removed with his family into Boston—but having to go out to Quincy, Wednesday Evening to deliver a second Lecture at the Lyceum, he passed the Night at my house, and returned to Boston Thursday Morning.— His mother was then so much better that Dr Holbrook favoured the ïdea of her leaving home this day— It is remarkable that while the weather was so beautiful here the first half of the last week, Charles says it was so bad there, that the delay to the departure of my family was immaterial— The first part of my Speech of 14. October, was published in the National Intelligencer of this Morning— The proof for the remainder of the Speech to be printed to-morrow, was sent to me immediately after breakfast; and the Note appended to the Speech, about one P.M— The revisal occupied me, the whole morning, and I took the note as revised to the Intelligencer Office, where I saw Mr Seaton— I had thought of bespeaking 50 copies of the Speech in pamphlet form; but doubting whether after all, it will excite much attention, and whether I do not greatly over estimate its interest to the very few readers of long speeches, I concluded only to bespeak 6 copies of the tri-weekly Intelligencer of to-morrow which will contain the whole— I passed an hour from the dusk of Evening at Mr W. S. Smith’s.— He received a Letter from his Sister, Mrs De Wint, of Saturday last at New-York—mentioning the death that morning of Bryan Johnson, second Son of Alexander B. Johnson of Utica— A fine young man, whom I had only once seen, about thirteen months ago, when he brought me to Quincy a Letter of introduction from his father.— I answered a Letter, received three days since from Alexander H. Everett, who in his political career has got into a false position, and who asks my assistance, when it could not serve him.
7. III:45. Tuesday

The remainder of my Speech, upon Nouns, Pronouns, Verbs and Adverbs, (a perilous name) was published in the Daily National Intelligencer, and the whole Speech in the tri-weekly paper. It is by the care I have taken more correctly printed than I believe any production of mine, ever was before— I called at the Intelligencer Office and bespoke of Mr Seaton half a dozen copies of the tri-weekly Paper, which I sent off by this Evening’s Mail.— Seaton mentioned to me a Letter from John P. King a Senator from Georgia, who made the most powerful Speech against the Sub-treasury Bill that was delivered in the Senate, and whom they are now tearing to pieces in Georgia for apostasy to his party— Among the other ingenious devices to run him down, they have resorted to a forgery, a pretended marginal note upon the Intelligencer, containing his Speech, attributed to the Editors of the Intelligencer and saying that it was not the Speech delivered but softened down all the personalities against Jackson and Van Buren; and charging it as cowardice in King, for which he was despised by the federalists— This is a party artifice, to decry the man, to counteract the force of the Speech— King has such a pack of hounds at his heels, for the most spirited and ablest speech of the Session, that he has announced his intention to resign his Seat in the Senate.— I called at Niles’s Register Office, but he was not there— One of his workmen told me however that they were at work upon my speech, for publication, in the next Saturday’s Register— I found at the Office a Boston daily Advertiser, containing Letters from a Mr Atwill, and from William Jackson, to Governor Edward Everett, about his opinions concerning the abolition of Slavery in the District of Columbia, and the annexation of Texas to this Union, with his answers— He is somewhat embarrassed, with his opinions heretofore expressed upon Slavery; but he is explicit enough now, and will lose very few, if any votes this year for his anti-abolitionism— It will give him trouble hereafter— I received at the Franklin Insurance Office, a dividend of 506:80. eight per Cent, for the a last half-year, which I deposited in the Bank of Washington. I met Mr Watterston, who told me that he had seen my Speech in this morning’s paper, and that it had a taking title— Towards Evening Mrs W. S. Smith, called here— She had just been visiting Mrs Madison, who told her that she wished to have a conversation with me— I drew two Bills of Exchange each for £500 Sterling, in the name of the Executors of Ward N. Boylston, upon Messrs. Baring brothers and Co. London, payable at 30 days sight—signed the three bills in each set; one dated this day and one to-morrow. Enclosed the first and second of both sets, in a Letter to Mrs Boylston, and Mr Curtis, retaining the third—leaving the name of the drawee blank— Unable to finish a Letter to my Son—
8. III.45 Wednesday.

I paid a morning visit to President Van Buren, and met at the top of the Stair-case, coming out from the Cabinet Mr Blair the Senior editor of the Globe Newspaper— He stop’d me and told me that my Speech in the Night ofFeby last was printed in the Globe, and
and that he would send me a copy of it— I had been only a few minutes with the President, when Mr Forsyth the Secretary of State came in with some papers, and I of course left them together— I went to Mrs. Towle’s, for the third sitting for my Portrait, but she was indisposed, and unable to paint, and sent a request that I would come again next Saturday— There was a young woman, who appears to be residing with her, copying a Portrait in her work-chamber— I went to the Capitol, and at the Clerk’s Office enquired for the answers from the States, to the Resolution adopted upon my Motion—calling for all the Acts of the State Legislatures relating to the suspension of Specie payments by the Banks.— There are answers from twelve States that there has been no Legislative enactment upon the subject— In five there have been, and copies of the acts are furnished— Mr Burch told me that most of these answers had been received within a few days, and he promised to send me a minute of them— They are materials on which I ought to labour abundantly— After returning home, I copied into my Letter-book, my Letter to Alexander H. Everett, and despatched it by the Mail, together with a long Letter to my Son, of which I have no copy.— I then paid a visit to Genl. Macomb, whom I found with his Son and his two daughters— Mrs Macomb was not there— His nephew, the Major came in while I was there— I came home—drew two Bills of exchange for the Executors of the Will of Ward N. Boylston, each for £500 Sterling upon the Brothers Baring and Co. London, at thirty days sight, and dated Boston 9. and 10. Novr. 1837— Wrote a Letter for the Executors to the Baring’s which I signed, and a Letter to my Co-Executors, to be copied to-morrow—
9. IV. Thursday.

The black man Nathan Allen came again, about the contribution to purchase his wife and children, which he finds it very difficult to accomplish— He said General Smith of Georgetown had agreed to endorse the balance of the sum which was to be paid for the redemption of his wife and children; but the doubt remains whether they will be emancipated— I told Allen to ask Mr Key to call on me— Mr Force came and said there was to be this Evening a Meeting of the American Historical Society, and he wished to inform them of my definitive answer, whether I would deliver their anniversary address in January next— I told him I feared it would be impossible. I should certainly not have time for its preparation— If the Society would now provide themselves with another speaker for that day, and would accept
accept a conditional engagement from me to deliver the address the next year, if my life and health should permit I would so undertake— Mr Force said he had one volume of the compilation which he with Matthew St. Clair Clark was making of historical documents, nearly ready and would send me a copy in a few days—and that Mr Fendall had engaged to write the preface for it— Mr Miller the Architect of the Public Buildings, brought me, he said at the request of Mr Robert Gilmor of Baltimore, the designs for the Inscriptions on the Monument in honour of George Washington erected by the State of Maryland— The Inscriptions were all as they had been settled by Mr Gilmor’s correspondence with me; but the date assigned for the appointment—of Washington as Commander in Chief of the American Armies of the Revolution was 3. June 1776— I told Mr Miller that was a mistake, and immediately recurred to the Journals of the Revolutionary Congress, and shewed him the entry of the appointment as of the 15th. of June 1775— This incident led me to reflect how important it is that in monumental inscriptions the names and the dates should be correct— I called at the Pension-Office, and left with Mr Edwards enquiries concerning claims to Pensions of two widows, proposed in a Letter from William Ellis of Dedham— I walked to the Capitol, and took out from the Library, Smith’s Wealth of Nations, M’Culloch’s edition— I saw there the 2d volume of M. L. Davis’s life of Aaron Burr; and on opening it, found several very interesting Letters between him and his daughter Theodosia the wife of Joseph Alston of South-Carolina— Mr Burch of the Clerk’s Office gave me a list of the States from which answers have been received, about their Laws relating to the suspension of specie payments by the Banks— On returning home, I found that Mr Key had called while I was out— Returning home I was stopped by Mr Rives, one of the Editors of the Globe, who told me they were about to publish in the Globe my Speech, published in the National Intelligencers of last Monday and Tuesday— And he enquired, if I wished it should be published in one paper— I said certainly.— He said it must then be in a very small type— I said they might print it as best suited themselves.— Only I wished them to print it with the Note; and the Bill as it finally passed, and as it is in the National Intelligencer. He said they would— I spoke to him of the Letters from Richard Pollard at Santiago de Chile— He said they had published the one of them— He gave me also a copy of the Appendix to the Congressional Globe, containing my night Speech on the 2d. of March last, at the call of Balie Peyton of Tennessee, which I had supposed never was published— At the dusk, I went and spent an hour with Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith, and soon after I came home, my dear wife, with Mary, and her two children, Ellen Goods, Thomas Nelson and Rachel Campbell, came in, to my great joy, all safe, from Quincy.—
10. V:45. Friday

My wife and family, left Quincy last Monday morning—had a very boisterous passage, from Providence to New-York, where they were obliged to stop one night— They came to Philadelphia on Wednesday, and from thence yesterday— Their arrival removed a heavy load from my Spirits— I received a Letter from Mr Anthony Collamore of Pembroke, enclosing two to J. L. Edwards, the Commissioner of Pensions, which I took to him— He gave me his report on the two cases, mentioned in the letter of Mr Ellis of Dedham, and promised a speedy report on the cases referred to in Mr Collamore’s Letters— The black man Allen had come to me again this morning in great solicitude about his wife and children, and I told him I would see again Mr Key— I went accordingly both to his House, and to his Office in the City Hall; but did not find him; I then went to the Office of the National Intelligencer and saw Mr Seaton. Mr Key came in while I was there— Upon conversing with him I found he would give no assurance that Dorcas Allen and her children will be free, if they should be purchased from Birch— By the Law of the place, they are assets of the Estate of Gideon Davis, upon which there never has been any Administration; neither his widow nor her second husband Rezin Orme, had any right to sell them, and the sale to Birch was a mere nullity— Mr Key said the Corporation of Washington were the only creditors of Davis, and it was not likely they would ever disturb the purchase from Birch— Seaton asked me for the manuscript of my Speech on the deposit postponement Bill—for early to-morrow morning— The day was absorbed by avocations— Afternoon visit from Mr James Whitcomb. He wrote me a Letter a few days since, addressing to me sundry enquiries upon which he wished to have a conversation with me— The Appointment of Collector at Boston—Slavery—Texas; the Currency; upon all which I gave him freely my opinions, and he said he should wish to have further conversations with me. He wanted that Jotham Lincoln, or Mr Parmenter should be appointed Collector at Boston— He thought Mr Van Buren, would be admonished by the recent indications of popular opinions to modify his system of policy; and particularly by the result of the elections in the City of New-York, where information had been received this afternoon that the whigs had a majority of 2900 votes. Mr Frye, and Mr. and Mrs. W. S. Smith spent the Evening here— They had heard nothing of the result of the New-York election.
11. IV. Saturday.

No fire in my chamber—but in the bed-chamber and dining room— I received a Letter from Solomon Lincoln, requesting me to subscribe for the Daily National Intelligencer, for one year for the Hingham reading room— I went to the National Intelligencer Office and made the subscription accordingly— Mr Gales was there, and sent for the Madisonian of yesterday containing a Letter of Reuben M. Whitney, to Martin Van Buren, President of the United States; and a Letter from F. O. J. Smith of Maine to the Editor of some newspaper; both upon the sub-treasury, or Bank and State divorce Bill— Gales spoke also of a Letter from Joseph L. May to his constituents, of which Mr Whitcomb had spoken to me yesterday, and which no doubt the one that May told me he
he intended to publish— I called at the Office of Niles’s Register, but he was gone to Baltimore— The Register of this day has my Speech, on the Bank Balance Bill, republished entire with the Note and the Bill— I went to the City Hall, and delivered to him a Letter to himself and one to William C. Greenleaf brought by my wife; and I took this opportunity to obtain at the Registry of Deeds, the Deed from the Corporation of the City of Washington, of the square N. 592, which I had left there in May 1835 to be recorded— Returning home I found at last the residence of Mr Whitcomb, the Commissioner of the General Land-Office, and left a card for him— I was engaged all the evening revising the reports by Otis and Stansberry, the reporters for the Intelligencer of my Speech on the Deposit postponement Bill— I have less time at my disposal than heretofore.— Mary and her daughter Fanny, both unwell.
12. IV:30. Sunday

I sent this morning, by a man who came from Mr Gales the manuscript of Otis’s portion of my Speech on the deposit postponement Bill—which I had revised—and I added a preliminary advertisement, necessary to shew the state of the question when I spoke. In the morning I heard at the Presbyterian Church Mr Fowler from Psalm 103:13. “Like as a father pitieth his children, so the Lord pitieth them that fear him.”— The relation between God and man, likened to that between a father and his child is the most amiable aspect in which religion can be presented to the heart— It is not the most congenial to the calvinistic creed which rather exhibits God as an inexorable judge— But it is with Mr Fowler as with other Presbyterian divines, whom I have known— The benevolence of his nature works at cross purposes with his doctrinal faith— He is a tender-hearted man, and appears delighted to expound any passage in Scripture which exhibits the Deity with parental affections towards mankind— Mrs Frye and her Son Thomas dined with us— I had called at the Intelligencer Office, and seen both Gales and Seaton. I gave them the manuscript of Stansberry containing his report of the remainder of my Speech revised by myself, with a connecting paragraph between his report and that of Otis and a supplementary paragraph at the close— Stansberry’s report is very imperfect— He is a very good reporter when he intends to be so; but when I first came into the House, he was laying every member, who took part in the debates, and who would submit to the tax under contribution for reporting his Speeches; and he claimed the same tribute from me— I gave him some trifle, upon his allegation that it was a customary gratuity paid him by others; but after the first Congress in which I sat as a member of the House, I declined giving him any thing more.— Others did the same. But since that time he has very seldom reported any speech of mine, and when he did, has never done me justice— At the late Session, Otis and he were joint reporters
reporters for the National Intelligencer, and relieved each other hour and hour— Otis took the first hour of my speech on the postponement Bill, and Stansberry the remainder— There was so much reference in it to figures and numbers, that perhaps no reporter could have taken it very correctly, but Stansberry’s portion of the work required more correction, than that of his Associate— Gales told me that the proof, of the whole Speech, would be ready for me, if I would call at the Office about noon to morrow, for publication on Tuesday. While I was there Mr Featherstonhaugh came in— Mrs Frye, and her Son Thomas dined with us— After which at St. John’s Church Mr Hawley read the service, for the 25th. Sunday after Trinity, and preached a short discourse from Psalm 36.9. “For with thee, is the fountain of life: in thy light shall we see light.” Mrs. Smith was here when I came home— I took Mary-Louisa with me to Church, morning and afternoon— Dr Huntt was here to visit Fanny confined to bed with a fever— Her mother too has a severe cold. My wife received this Evening a Letter from her Sister Mrs Adelaide Hellen; with an old correspondence between herself and Mr and Mrs Boyd.

Nathan and Dorcas Allen were here this morning— He had not yet made up the subscription for the balance between 330 and 475 dollars— General Walter Smith of Georgetown having promised to endorse Allen’s note for the former sum, if he could procure the remainder to pay Birch for a Bill of Sale of the woman and the two children.— But he said that General Smith had examined at the Registry of Wills, Davis’s Will, and that by the Will the woman and children were bequeathed to Davis’s wife, and therefore her second wife husband had an undoubted right to sell them— I told him that whenever the Bill of sale should be ready, I would give the check for 50 dollars which I had promised— He came again twice in the course of the day—once while I was out, and again after I returned— He then told me that Birch had again taken the two children, and put them into the jail; and would carry them away, if the money was not paid— That General Smith now said, if I would pay the fifty dollars, he would undertake with the other subscriptions, to pay the whole sum and take the bill of sale.— He repeated that General Smith was entirely satisfied with the validity of Birch’s title, and that he had the right to make the sale— I then gave him the check for 50 dollars in Bills payable in Bills at the Bank of Washington to Walter Smith Esqr or his order; and told him when the affair should be completed to bring me the Bill of sale that I may see it— I could pursue the question of Birch’s title no further, without becoming liable to the imputation of shrinking from my own promise, and prevaricating upon the performance of my engagement— Yet I still doubt the legality of the sale to Birch, and whether the complete emancipation of the woman and children will be effected— I could not take the course of the Law, for Mr Key told me that if upon a writ of Habeas Corpus Birch’s title
title should be disproved, still as they were slaves they could not be discharged— Such is the condition of things in these shambles of human flesh, that I could not now expose this whole horrible transaction, but at the hazard of my life— Any attempt to set aside this purchase for illegality would be stigmatized as mean and dishonourable— Iniquity must have its whole range— I therefore made the promise of 50 dollars, for their emancipation, and have now paid it, without even being sure of effecting it—rather than attempt, to bereave the man-robber of his spoils— I went to the Office of the National Intelligencer, saw Mr Seaton, and revised the proof slips of my speech on the 29th. of September, upon Pickens’s motion for reconsideration of the vote passing to the third reading, the Bill to postpone the fourth instalment of the deposite with the States, under the act of 23 June 1836. the question was upon the reconsideration of the vote— The argument was upon my amendment to Pickens’s Amendment— It is to be published to-morrow Morning, and will occupy not more than three Columns and an half of the paper. Mr Seaton gave me some of the last Boston Newspapers, full of the bustle of electioneering— At the dusk of Evening I went and passed an hour with Mr and Mrs. W. S. Smith.— Answered Letters from Solomon Lincoln, and J. William Ellis—
14. IV:30. Tuesday.

Rain all night and snow this morning, which was my signal for having a fire made again in my writing chamber— I have this Season, for health and for economy adopted a rule to keep that chamber as cool as I can bear it, and write without discomfort; that is without benumbed fingers; and have discontinued it, whenever the mildness of the weather or the warmth of the Sun made it unnecessary— I have omitted, which I ought not to have done to keep account of the number of days, upon which I have had fire kindled in it, but it does not exceed fourteen, and I therefore assume that the average time for making fire in this chamber is the first of November, and not before—and that its average continuance should be to the first of April—between those two days there will be very few if any days when fire can be spared— In the months of October and of April, fires must be occasional—about half the time; so as a general result the time necessary for keeping a fire in a chamber with a Southern exposure, in this Climate is from the 15th. of October to the 15th. of April—half the year.— But unless care is taken for the constant admission of the Sun it will be wanted at least six weeks more.— I called this morning at the Office of the Secretary of War, with a Letter from William Thomas of Plymouth, relating to a widow Pension claim, to ask a relaxation from the rigour of the Rules of Evidence in
in cases where equity seems to require it— But he was at the President’s, and I took the Letter to Mr Edwards the Commissioner of Pensions—and I received from him unfavourable answers in the cases of Mary Magoun and of Ruth Garnett— I walked to the Capitol, and took out from the Library of Congress, the second Volume of Judge Story’s Commentaries on the Constitution—necessary for me to write out my remarks on the case of the Mississippi Election, at the late Session of Congress— Then to Niles’s Register Office, where he promised to republish in the next Saturday’s Register, my Speech of the 29th. of September last, on the Bill to postpone the payment of the fourth instalment of the deposite with the States, which is first published in this days National Intelligencer.— I then went to that office, and took six copies of the Country paper of this day, which I sent to my Son, to Edward Everett, to the Editors of the Old Colony Memorial at Plymouth, of the Hingham Gazette, and of the Quincy Patriot—and to William Plumer junr.— This and a Letter to Edward Everett, was the labour of the day.— Fiery Northern Light.
15. III:45. Wednesday

Our Coachman Thomas has been suddenly taken ill— Mrs Goods’s daughter Mrs Mitchell suffers with a return of fits to which she has been subject— Mary’s cough continues obstinate— Fanny is recovering, and Louisa’s travelling cold is passing off— A person by the name of Kingsbury a native of Massachusetts, but now and since the year 1821 an inhabitant of Cleveland in the state of Ohio, came and told me that he was preparing a Memorial to Congress, praying their attention to the observance of the Sabbath, and particularly for the repeal of a provision in an Act of Congress passed inrequiring that the Post-Offices should be kept open on the Lord’s day— He asked me, what I thought would be done in Congress, with such a Memorial— I said that my own impression would be that it should be received, read, printed, and referred to a Committee for a report— But I enquired whether his objection extended to the traveling of the Mails on Sunday— He said no—he considered that as desperate— But great licentiousness, particularly in the country towns and villages, resulted from allowing the Post-Offices on Sundays— They were the resort of idlers, intemperate and dissolute persons; and they held out an example too apt to be followed by mechanics, traders, tradesmen and shop-keepers, to keep their shops open and make the day a day of ordinary labour. I said I had not been aware of any Law requiring the Post-Offices to be kept always open
open, and that in the town where I reside, it is not in fact open on Sundays— In the principal cities, the speedy conveyance and prompt receipt of their Letters was important to so many men of business, I supposed it would be impossible to alter the arrangements for despatching and distributing the Letters by the Mail; and for effecting any change whatever, I thought there would be little prospect of success, for any single Petitioner, or Memorialist. If he should conclude to present a Memorial, I could only promise him for myself, that I would vote, for its being received, read, printed and referred to a Committee— He thanked me, and intimated his intention to revise the memorial that he had prepared, and then come and show it to me— Dr Huntt was also here—a piteous object to behold, apparently in the last Stage of a consumption— Ill in bed all morning, and then got up in desparation, and went to a dinner at Mr Poinsett’s, where he ate and drank without restraint, every thing that came, Champagne and all; without any effect that he perceived either good or bad— He is a bare living skeleton; but still cheerful and sprightly— I went to Mrs Towles, and gave her a short, cold and rather drowsy sitting— Wrote a few lines to Charles, and wrote out in part my first remarks, on the 3d. of October upon the Mississippi election question— Clear morning followed by a chilly and cloudy day—
16. V. Thursday.

In writing out my remarks upon the case of the Mississippi Election, at the late Session of Congress, I wanted a Report of the Speech of Arphaxed Loomis of New-York, who immediately preceded me in the debate, and whose opinions I combated— I went to the Office of the National Intelligencer to enquire if they had the manuscript of Mr Loomis’s Speech; but I met Mr Seaton going out, and Gales who came in while I was sitting in the Office could not ascertain whether they had got Loomis’s Speech or not— I read at the office a Letter of Major Downing announcing that they have got the two Pollises afloat— I urged Gales to republish Reuben M Whitney’s Letters to Martin Van Buren President of the United States, as they are now in the course of publication in the Madisonian— I thought them important as shewing the character of Jackson’s confidential correspondences, while he was President of the United States— When I came home I found Mrs Giusta here— Mrs Smith was here after dinner; and Mr Cherry brought me a Letter of introduction from Mr R. R. Gurley the Secretary to the Colonization Society— He left with me, the November number of the African Repository and Columbian Journal, containing an Article called the Monument—a Dream—written by him, which he requested me to read, and said he wished to have a conversation with me concerning it, afterwards. In the Evening I read to the Ladies three chapters of the Life of Aaron Burr, by Matthew L. Davis— Two extraordinary men—perhaps such as no other part of this Union could have produced— Burr’s life, take it altogether was such, as in any country of sound morals, his friends would be desirous of burying in profound oblivion— The Son and Grandson of two able and eminent calvinistic divines, he had no religious principle, and little if any sense of responsibility to a moral Governor of the Universe— He lost both his father and
and mother before he was three years old, and with them appears to have lost all religious education— He lived and died as a man of the world— Brave, generous, hospitable and courteous; but ambitious, rapacious, faithless, and intriguing— This character raised him within a hair’s breadth of the Presidency of the United States—sunk him within a hair’s breadth of a gibbet and a halter for treason; and left him for the last thirty years of his life a blasted monument of Shakespear’s vaulting ambition— There are in the chapters that I read this Evening three of his collegiate Essays, something above mediocrity; but not much— His principle for Style was simplicity.
17. IV:15. Friday.

Dr. Mayo paid me a morning visit, with a prospectus of a book which he proposes to publish under the title of Eight Years residence in Washington— That is, a secret History of the kitchen Cabinet, the Hickory Club, and the Administration of Andrew Jackson— He proposes a volume of about 500 pages, and wanted some written recommendation of the work, to allure subscribers— This I declined, and told him that if his disclosures should be such as are promised in his prospectus he would have no need other than authentic evidence of the facts, of recommendation to obtain subscribers or readers. Dr. Mayo is one of those Office hunters and busybodies who during Jackson’s Administration, under the mask of reform were in a continual struggle to turn out of the executive Offices all the incumbents except his devoted tools, and to put themselves and such as themselves into their places— Mayo was the principal agent of the Hickory Club, acting under the impulse of Amos Kendall— But in his purposes of reform he assumed a principle which did by no means suit them, and that was removals should be made only for moral, or official misconduct, or open abuse of the Administration, and that it should be applied equally, to individuals of their own party, as well as to others— He offered to the club a resolution to that effect, to the Hickory Club, which he says was almost unanimously rejected. In his pamphlet already published, called a Chapter of Sketches on Finance Dr. Mayo has disclosed a curious history of the transactions of this Hickory Club; but of the whole pamphlet the most curious part is a Letter to President Jackson from himself,—under the secret of the Masonic cypher, dated 2 December 1830. containing a detailed account of Samuel Houston’s conspiracy against Texas at that time— And Dr Mayo shewed me this morning a confidential Letter from President Jackson, in his own hand-writing to Mr Fulton, then Secretary of the Territory of Arkansas, and now a Senator from that State, dated 10. December 1830. sternly denouncing this project against Texas, and instructing him by all the means in his power to defeat and break it up— These papers the Dr told me, were all returned to him, from President Jackson in 1836—at his own request—and among was he supposed by mistake this original Letter from Jackson—but whether it had ever been sent to Fulton he did not know, and doubted: but he referred to it as a demonstration of the duplicity of Jackson’s administration, with regard to the relations of the Country with Mexico and Texas— It is so, and proves that Jackson’s bold and dashing character was nevertheless capable of double-dealing, worthy of Ferdinand the Catholic or
or of Tiberius Caesar— All the proceedings relating to Texas and Mexico have been in the same style.— The expositions of Dr Mayo, if he publishes them, will be documentary histories of the Jackson Administration— And he was himself one of the principal ingredients of that character— I told him I would take one of his books but from my peculiar position, could have no agency whatever in promoting its publication— He had another document, like which he said there were unfortunately too many. It was a record of testimony of 12 or 15. witnesses in a judicial Court in New-Hampshire discrediting John H. Sherburne, as a person of no veracity, till the judge told the Counsel that he needed produce no more witnesses for their number already exceeded that of the Jury— He said notwithstanding this Sherburne who was a clerk in the Navy had been very recently appointed a disbursing Officer— Mr Butler the Attorney General, with Lieutenant Governor Troup of New-York paid me a morning visit— Mrs Madison called but Mrs Adams could not receive her— Dolly Cutts was here— I walked round the Capitol— Meeting on my way Mr Saml. L. Gouverneur just from New-York. W. Cost Johnson, and Edward Wyer— My wife was taken suddenly ill after dinner—and Mary yet suffers with an obstinate cough
18. IV:30. Saturday.

Mrs Adams had a bad Night, and was confined the whole of this day to her bed.— I finished writing out my remarks, on the case of the Mississippi election, at the recent Session of Congress— I took them to the Office of the National Intelligencer, but neither Gales nor Seaton was there.— Met and walked with William Cost Johnson, who has just published his evening Speech of the 12th. of October; one of the most extraordinary Speeches that I ever heard in that Hall, full of wisdom—full of wit—keen as a razor with Satire, beaming with philosophical truth—glowing with ardent patriotism and spoken after dinner— He never speaks in the morning— His mind is like the fallen Archangel Majestic though in ruin. He is yet a young man, and was first a member of the 23d. Congress— During the first and long Session of which he was in very bad health—often confined from attendance in the House, and unable to take part in the debates— On the last Night of the second Session, or one or two Nights before he made one of these eloquent but intemperate speeches in which he said that the general Post-Office was corrupt from the crown of the head to the sole of the foot— He was called on to except the Postmaster General Barry, and refused— He says in this Speech that Barry’s son challenged him that same night, but afterwards withdrew the challenge— That he was threatened with three or four challenges, and four or five canings; and that while these threats were held over his head, he refused to make any explanation whatever—but that now, Mr Barry being dead he took pleasure in saying
saying that he had not intended to charge the Postmaster General personally with corruption; but that he was responsible for tolerating it in his subalterns.— He told me to day that he was almost afraid to send me a copy of his Speech. I began to answer a Letter received a few days since from Dr. W. E. Channing, intending to make it very short; but after filling one sheet found I had more to say, I know not how much— Weather warm—omitted fire in my writing chamber—
19. IV. Sunday.

My wife recovering from her illness, and able to leave her bed; but not her chamber— Dr Huntt was here having been very ill all night, and looking as if he would not live a week— Mary’s cough is still unyielding and almost incessant— I took the two children with me to the Presbyterian Church— Mr Fowler preached from Acts 24:–25. “Go thy way for this time; when I have a convenient season, I will call for thee”—not upon the story of Felix and Drusilla; but merely upon the procrastination of repentance— He did not read the first part of the verse— After dinner I took only Louisa to St. John’s Church and heard Mr Hawley— He read the service for the 26th Sunday after Trinity, and the collect for the 6th. Sunday after the Epiphany— His Discourse, of not more than ten minutes was from Zechariah 6.12. “And speak unto him, saying, Behold the man whose name is in The BRANCH: and he shall grow up out of his place, and he shall build the temple of the Lord: 13. Even he shall bear the glory, and shall sit and rule upon his throne; and he shall be a priest upon his throne: and the counsel of peace shall be between them both.[”]— This is an exceedingly mysterious chapter, and the two verses of the Text, perhaps more mysterious than all the rest, but Mr. Hawley did not attempt to explain it— I was going at the dusk to visit Mr and Mrs Smith, when I met them coming to our house— They spent the Evening here. I was occupied all the leisure of the day upon my Letter to Dr Channing, which yet I did not finish—and I took the occasion to read the correspondence reported to the House of Representatives concerning the boundary with Mexico, and the proposition for the cession of Texas.— Mr Poinsett was instructed by Mr Clay in 1825 and 1827. to propose the purchase of portions of the Mexican territories, and these instructions were renewed afterwards by Mr Van Buren in 1829. and at later periods to Mr Butler— I was so much engaged that a second day’s Diary crept in arrear.
20. IV:30. Monday

Pumphrey and Harvey were visitors for the settlement of accounts— Mr Kingsbury brought me the draught of his intended Memorial to Congress praying for the repeal of a part of one Section of the Post-Office Law; being that which requires the Postmasters to keep the Offices open every day of the week—the memorial is long, and he left it with me, requesting me to read it, and said, he would call on me to have some conversation with me concerning it to-morrow— Dr Huntt was here again—a walking skeleton; but wih a voice as strong and clear as when he was in health— I took my remarks on the Mississippi election made on the 3d. of October to the National Intelligencer Office and
and asked Mr Seaton, if he would publish them in the paper. He promised to do so, immediately after the Meeting of Congress—the question will in all probability come up again at the next Session. I therefore took my manuscript back with me; and at last finished my Letter to Dr. Channing—the most carelessly written of any Letter that I ever wrote— It is upon the question concerning the annexation of Texas to this Union—a question of far deeper root and more overshadowing branches than any or all others that now agitate this Country— Dr. Channing’s Letter to Mr Clay, of which he sent me a copy, discusses the subject with great power— I had opened it, by my Speech in the House of Representatives on the 25th. of May 1836— By far the most noted Speech that I ever made— I have a Spanish translation of it, published in Mexico, and nearly the whole of it, is republished in the Appendix to the second volume of Miss Martineaus work upon America— Dr Channing’s Letter enquires of me what is the present aspect here of the Texian annexation question— I have answered him what it has been—what it is—what it will be— My answer is a Letter to posterity, which will reach its address—but it is strictly confidential and so carelessly written, that if I were not thumb-screwed for time, I ought to write it over again, and burn it as a brouillon— Let it go—but if prayer can avail I implore divine assistance to prepare me for this debate in the House— My wife is recovering.
21. V. Tuesday

Mr Kingsbury came, and took back his draught of a memorial to Congress— It prays for the repeal of a part of one section of the Post-Office Law, enacted in 1810 and again in 1825. which requires that the Post-Offices should be kept open for the delivery of Letters every day of the week— His argument is that this commands labour on the Sabbath, in direct contradiction to the 4th. Commandment, and to the institution of the Christian Sabbath.— The memorial is long and well written, and strongly reasoned. He assumes that the People of the United States are a Christian People by profession and therefore bound by the Laws of Christianity which forbid labour on the Sabbath— And gives in proof the frequent instances of proclamations by the Revolutionary Congress for fast days, and days of Thanksgiving. It alleges also the moral influences of a strict observance of the Sabbath, and the licentiousness encouraged and promoted by the disregard of it, thus sanctioned by the authority of the Law— I told Mr Kingsbury that I was myself an observer of the Sabbath, and in the general practice of attending on public worship, twice every Sunday— But I thought there might be some question, as to the accuracy of his definition of the term labour— It might be denied that the mere keeping of the Post-Office open, and delivery of Letters on Sunday was labour— I said he was aware that in antient days, as well as among different denominations of Christians in modern ages there had been great diversities and oppositions of opinion and practice with regard to this commandment and its application— I cited the case of the massacre of the Jewish army mentioned in the book of the Maccabees because they held it unlawful to fight on the Sabbath-day and
and their decree that thenceforward they would fight in battle, if attacked, on the Sabbath, (1 Macabees 2.41) I cited also the saying of Jesus Christ, when he was reproached, because his disciples plucked the grain—that the Sabbath was made for man, and not Man for the Sabbath— And his reference to the case of David, who had taken the shew bread, which it was lawful only for the Priests to eat— I spoke also of the Roman Catholic understanding which devotes to recreation amusements and Sports all the portions of this day except those devoted to public worship— And I added that in my own opinion I could hardly consider the mere keeping open of the post-office, and the delivery of Letters as labour forbidden by the Law of the Sabbath—Jewish or Christian— Mr Kingsbury took these observations kindly without being satisfied by them— I told him that if he chose to have his memorial presented I would give him every aid in my power to have it printed and referred to a Committee; but doubted whether the house would treat it so kindly— I advised him to have it presented in fair copies to both to the House and to the Senate— That to the House, by the Member from his own District, of Cleveland, who he said was Mr John W. Allen— And I advised him to suggest to Mr Allen to move the reference of the memorial to the Post-Office, or the judiciary Committee—rather to the latter, if he could ascertain that Mr Thomas the Chairman was favourable to the object— I walked round the Capitol for exercise, before dinner— Mr and Mrs Smith spent the evening here
22. V. Wednesday

There was a riotous assemblage of people, perhaps 300 in number with a Cannon, who went round last Night to the President’s House, and the House of some of the Heads of Departments, discharged their cannon, and made much disturbance, in celebration of the whig victories in the late elections; especially in the State of New-York— I heard little of it myself, though it once awaked me out of sleep; and I knew not what it was— This effervescence of popular feeling is too common, and too little discountenanced by any of the predominating parties—both of them use the populace to glorify their triumphs and to depress their enemies; and both of them suffer for it in turn— The most atrocious case of mob rioting whichever disgraced this Country happened on the Night of the 7th. of this Month at Alton in the State of Illinois, where a man by the name of Lovejoy, one of the leading abolitionists of the time has been striving to establish a Newspaper— Three times he had imported printing presses in the place; and three times they had been destroyed by mobs, and once or twice, the Offices in which they were placed— The fourth time, the press was imported, and deposited in a Merchant’s warehouse— The mob assembled in the Night; surrounded the warehouse, and demanded that the press should be delivered up to them. It was refused— They assailed the house with musquetry—forced their way into it; set fire to the roof of the building; shot Lovejoy dead—wounded several others, till the press was delivered up to them, which they broke to pieces and threw into the river— One of the assailants also by the name of Bishop was also killed in the affray— This Lovejoy wrote me a Letter last January, which I answered in April— He was a man of strong religious, consciencious feeling, deeply indignant at what he deemed the vices and crimes of the age— Such men are often fated to be martyrs, and he has fallen a martyr to the cause
cause of human freedom— I went and sat again to Mrs Towle for my portrait. Her husband was there, and inclined to talk politics from which however I preferred to divert the conversation— Returning home I met Mr. Pedrich the Sculptor, and his wife. He told me, he was employed at the new Treasury Department building— Saw Mr S. H. Smith also at his house, and he spoke to me about the whig Charivari, of last Night— The Summer which for the last week had returned closed this evening, with a distant lightening cloud and a miniature hurricane— I answered a Letter from R. Shurtliff—inviting me in the name of two united Literary Societies at Dartmouth College, Hanover, New-Hampshire, to deliver an Address before them, the day before their next commencement—which I decline—and a Letter from S. S. Gregory at Sand lake, New-York, at best an eccentric, though apparently a very benevolent man— I received and read Governor Edward Everett’s Address to the Massachusetts Charitable Mechanic Association, at their first exhibition and Fair, on the 20th. of last September.— Admirable, as all his occasional discourses are— There is annexed to it a hymn by Mr Pierpont, scarcely less beautiful— The radical idea both of the Address and hymn is in Charles Sprague’s Ode upon Art, and thus it is that thought flies from mind to mind, brightening and expanding as it goes till it fills the universe with a blaze of glory.
23. VI. Thursday.

The change of climate by the sweeping gale of last Evening, which continued furious through the Night, and brought a clear sky and Northwestern frost this morning was very great— It was the transition from Summer to Winter in twelve hours— But the Sun kept my chamber warm, and I needed no fire in it till the Evening, and then had one for not more than half an hour.— I consumed much of the morning in reading Mr Preston’s Speech in the Senate, on the Sub-treasury, or divorce of Bank and State Bill—a strong, solid, argumentative speech; brilliant with imagery, and not overcharged with ornament— Scrupulously respectful to his Colleague Calhoun, and yet exposing in a clear light his Phaetontic course— There is an involuntary train of reasoning running through it in favour of a Bank of the United States, without the moral courage to avow the conclusion to which it tends—a complacency to the State Banks, ill deserved by them, and the radical weakness of the Speech— A capillary tube of nullification scarcely perceptible, but imparting poison to all the wholesome waters of the stream. It is one of those Speeches, of which multitudes are delivered almost every day in both Houses of Congress— Full of Eloquence—dazzling with beauty, sparkling with Wit—radiant with sentiment, beaming with philosophy, and yet radically defective in the basement story of moral principle— Ardent Patriotism, generous feeling, benevolent sentiment, elegant language, literature, courtesy, all the charms of eloquence are here, but the foundation of all wisdom, moral principle is wanting. Mr Preston approves and applauds the suspension of Specie payments by the Banks, an act of flagrant immorality in
in itself—perhaps excusable from necessity, but even then only so far as that necessity is not imputable to themselves. The suspension of Specie payments is a breach of faith—a general violation of promises, and a dissolution of the right of property, the foundation of human Society. A little leaven leveaneth the whole lump. I walked round the Capitol before dinner, and resumed the biographical sketch. The two children dined at their aunt Smith’s— In the evening I read two or three chapters in M. L. Davis’s Memoirs of the Life of Aaron Burr. There is something romantic in his Canada campaign with Arnold and Montgomery— He seems to have had a passion for high adventure; an inflexible will, and invincible perseverance in pursuing it; but no judgment in adapting his means to his ends; and a capricious levity in passing from an object obtained to one unattainable— Ambition of military fame. Ambition of conquest over female virtue was the duplicate ruling passion of his life— His headstrong obstinacy in going with Arnold to Canada, might have been admirable if dictated by pure and devoted patriotism, but the same Spirit urged him to leave Arnold, and to execute his determination in defiance of his remonstrances and of all military subordination— The account of his very brief residence in the family of General Washington is not clearly given— Washington saw through him at a glance— There was nothing congenial in their characters to each other— His adventures with Miss Moncrieffe, afterwards Mrs. Coghlan, form rather a pleasant episode— Mr Davis censures with sufficient severity Burr’s preposterous vanity in affecting to be an homme à bonnes fortunes—but does not cast over it the ridicule which it deserves.
24. V. Friday.

The cold weather continues, and a few flakes of snow floating in the atmosphere, heralded a storm which passed away for this time. We had declined the invitation to dine with President Van Buren, and excepting my daily walk before dinner round the Capitol, I passed the remainder of the day and Evening at home— Morning visit from Mr Hulme of Philadelphia, who had heretofore ha with me some communications on the subject of Astrology— Of these he said nothing now— But he was not satisfied with the whig victories at New-York, and thought they portended no improvement in the condition of the country— He said there was now a large excess of importations over the exportations, and that large orders had been sent to Europe for the importation of grain— I fear there is too much foundation of fact for these opinions—and that there will be no resumption of Specie payments by the banks, so long as there is any importation of grain— Two operations I believe are indispensable for the restoration of credit— 1. A great reduction of Bank paper. 2. A Bank of the United States— The reduction of Bank paper has not been attempted, in any place where the Banks have been allowed to continue making dividends— In New-York, where they are prohibited the Banks have largely reduced their liabilities, and are anxious to resume Specie payments— Hulme who is a native of England told me that he had observed to a warm whig in Philadelphia, that he believed nothing but a non-importation act would restore prosperity to the Country; to which the whig answered that the only non-importation
importation act that was needed was of men.— Returning from my walk I met Dr Mayo, who told me that he had been to Baltimore, and seen Mr Lucas the printer who had immediately agreed to print his book of six years residence at Washington; and that it would be forthwith printed— I received a petition dated the 20th. of October, signed by 36 women at a place called Juliet, Will County, in the State of Illinois, near the spot where E. P. Lovejoy a few days after was murdered. It prays for the abolition of Slavery and the Slave-trade in the District of Columbia. I read this Evening a few chapters in the Memoirs of Aaron Burr— There is an account of his saving Silliman’s brigade in the retreat from Long-Island in 1776. which affects very seriously the reputation of General Knox—and who is there living to defend him? It is very difficult to tell what is history in the details of our revolutionary War—but so it is of many of the events passing before us— In the controversy which arose from the battle of Monmouth, Burr, took the side of Lee, and he was of the party of Lee and Gates against Washington— When appointed Lieutenant Colonel of Malcolm’s Regiment, he wrote an impertinent Letter to General Washington accepting the appointment, but complaining that others his juniors had been promoted before him— He suffered so much in his health in consequence of the excessive heat and fatigue at and after the battle of Monmouth, that he asked for a furlough to be without pay—but not to lose his rank— Washington granted the furlough but declined to withdraw his pay— He preferred to remain in active service; and was stationed at West-Point, for the superinspection of the neutral ground. His accounts of the scouting parties are scarcely credible— This part of his Life however is very interesting—
25— VI. Saturday.

The morning was so cold that I could not write— I betook myself to reading Lewis Cass’s Discourse delivered before the American Historical Society on the 30th. of January 1836— The Society was formed on the 12th. of October 1835. as the anniversary of the discovery of Guanahani—St. Salvedor—Cat-Island, and the Western Hemisphere by Columbus—but they make no allowance for the change of the Calendar.— The objects of the Society declared in the 2d. Article of its Constitution are “to discover, procure and preserve whatever may relate to the Natural, Civil, Literary and Ecclesiastical History of America in general, and of the United States in particular[”]— This introductory Discourse was delivered by Mr Cass, then Secretary of War, and President of the Society—a second and similar Discourse was delivered at the second annual meeting of the Society, on the 20th. of January last by Levi Woodbury; then and now Secretary of the Treasury— They are both works of very considerable, though unequal merit, and although the latter has been very severely criticized.— I have been invited and very earnestly urged to deliver the next anniversary Discourse, and have declined, from a thorough conviction that I have not time to prepare such a one, as I should be willing to commit to the public ear and
and eye— But the purpose of this Society is good— These anniversary Discourses if properly composed may be made eminently useful— They tend to the improvement of the public mind— If I can contribute but one mite to that intellectual banquet which this Institution tenders annually to the fathers of the Land, here assembled, I ought not to withhold it— I have therefore an earnest desire to deliver this Discourse, and have promised, if the Society will provide themselves with another Orator for the next anniversary Meeting, I will use every exertion in my power to be prepared with a Discourse for that of the succeeding year— I come to this determination with trembling hope— I have little confidence in my own powers for this species of Composition; and the two preceding discourses, especially the first, are of an order, to fall beneath which would be not only inexpressibly mortifying, but would injure the cause, which I have it nearest my heart to promote— In coming to the determination to undertake the task, my first object was to examine critically what has been said by my predecessors, and for that purpose, I read this morning the Discourse of Mr Cass— I must read and analyse it again—but in looking over my papers this morning, I found a fragment of an Essay which I wrote fourteen or fifteen years ago, and left almost in embryo, which will serve for a basis of my proposed Discourse— I gave Mrs Towle another sitting this morning, and she said she would ask only for one more, which I promised for next Wednesday. Dr Joseph Kent, some time Governor of Maryland, and but now a Senator of the United States, one of the salt of the Earth, was killed yesterday, by a fall from his Horse, riding on his farm about 7. miles from this City— He was one of the best and most amiable of men— A man met me in the Street and stop’d me to say that he must have fallen in a fit of apoplexy; for that he was seen to fall, when his horse was going in a quiet and moderate pace. My eldest granddaughter Mary-Louisa was unwell this day so that the reading of the children to me in the Bible was again interrupted— In the Evening I read further in the Memoirs of Aaron Burr, to the time when he was compelled by ill health to resign his Commission in the army 10. March 1779. He appears to have been a very good partizan Officer—but there are several Letters and Certificates in his favour addressed to Commodore Valentine Morris in 1814. of the most extravagant character— That of Coll. Richard Platt, says that many people and he among the rest believed that Burr had supernatural sources of information.— The marvellous kills the probable.
26. IV: Sunday.

Louisa continues unwell— I took Fanny with me this morning to the Presbyterian church where Mr Fowler preached from 2. Corinthians 2.15. [“]For we are unto God a sweet savour of Christ, in them that are saved, and in them that perish— 16. To the one we are the savour of Death unto Death; and to the other the savour of life unto life— And who is sufficient for these things.” The last clause was omitted from the text.— The thought is one of the difficulties of St. Paul’s writings— A sweet savour of Christ in them that perish—a sweet savour of Death unto Death, needs explanation to convey the thought. But the meaning seems to be that the Gospel Ministry when unsuccessful becomes itself
itself an instrument of destruction— Mr Fowler preached with great earnestness, and made warm appeals to the impenitent of his congregation— That man is a vicious, wicked animal, is the fundamental doctrine of the Christian religion— That he cannot save himself from eternal punishment is the doctrine of the Catholic churches and of Calvin.— If he cannot save himself he is not a responsible being— That is the conclusion of Justice—and a conclusion from which I could not escape if I would— The Mission of Christ was to teach all mankind the way to Salvation— His death, an ignominious death, was necessary to the universal spread of his doctrine— He died for mankind as Curtius died for his Country— As Codrus died for his people— In this sense I can believe the doctrine of the atonement and in no other—Christ died as a man—not as God; and although his death was attended with peculiar circumstances of horror, it was after all but death, which the Stoic of Greece and Rome denied to be an evil, and which the Indian Savage inflicts and defies with equal indifference. In the same sense the Christian doctrine may be a savour of death unto death unto them that perish; but death is only the termination of existence upon earth, and what the apostle means by perishing is still undefined— After dinner I attended at St. John’s church alone— A stranger preached, and there were two young Ladies, strangers, in my pew— The service was for the 27th.
