Sunday after Trinity, and the text was from 2. Kings 7.3. And there were four leprous men, at the entering in of the gate: and they said one to another, Why sit we here until we die? 4. If we say, we will enter into the City, then the famine is in the city, and we shall die there; and if we sit still here we die also— Here the text stop’d— The remainder of the verse is— Now therefore come, and let us fall unto the host of the Syrians; if they save us alive, we shall live; and if they kill us, we shall but die.— The whole of the two verses would not have suited the doctrine of the preacher, which was that Christians should apply to themselves the reasoning of the four lepers, and instead of sitting still until they die resort to the truths of the gospel for their salvation— The Sermon was well written; and with the exception of some flourishes of elegant gesticulation, well delivered— I had a visit from a Mr Hammon of New-Bedford; merely from curiosity. The Ladies with Fanny went to Mr Frye’s, where their Son Thomas B. J. Frye is laid up with a swelling of the arm, threatening an abscess.— In the Evening I read further in the Memoirs of Aaron Burr, from the time of his leaving the army untill his marriage with Mrs Theodosia Prevost in April 1832— In the interval he studied Law— Davis says from 16 to 20 hours a day, which is a thumper— Was admitted to the bar, and commenced the practice at Albany. There is very little narrative, and nothing of much interest in the correspondence— Letters from William Patterson, Robert Troup, Peter Colt, and some others— Those of Troup, pourtraying his own distresses from poverty are the most affecting— The love-Letters between Burr and Mrs Prevost are mawkish— Hers are upon the whole the best—
27. V. Monday

Disqualifying cold in the morning— I read Mr Woodbury’s Discourse before the American Historical Society— Much inferior to that of Mr Cass— A very common-place panegyric upon our National Literary character: dressed up in new phrases, obscure almost throughout— Thoughts that would be bold if they dared, but always hedged in by qualifications and after thoughts, forming a style so complex that no one can understand it— The most remarkable example of it is in the passage where arguments are urged against the abolition of Slavery. They are muffled up in so many folds that it is scarce possible to make out what it means. Yet there are a multitude of small thoughts, strung together upon a coarse and vulgar string so as to make a show not with out brilliancy— He works with infinite labour to show why we are not so eminent in literary composition as the Englishmen of the other hemisphere—and finishes by giving no good reason at all— Old Mr Carusi came, and asked me for a Letter of recommendation to Mr Forsyth, Secretary of State— I asked him what he wanted it for— He told me that he wanted it to obtain the appointment of Consul of the United States at Naples— Carusi is himself a Neapolitan by birth, between 60 and 70 years of age, when Captain R. V. Morris of our Navy, brought home with him, as one of a band of Music, from a Mediterranean Cruise— He settled here and has brought up a large family of children, and acquired an affluent Estate. He said Mr Hammett, who has been many years Consul at Naples was dead; and that he himself had claims to inheritance of property in that Country, which required his presence to make them effective— There was to be sure no salary attached to the Office, but it would give him the means of asserting his rights with more efficiency— I said to him that he knew Mr Forsyth as well as he knew me— That my recommendation would rather disserve than serve him, and that I was not upon terms with the administration to recommend to them any one for public office— I had a further reason for refusing which I did not communicate to him. Which was that without knowing any special fact against him, I hear no very good report of his character— I walked round the Capitol before dinner; and stop’d at Mr Force’s office to enquire if he had Adair’s History of the North American Indians, which I wished to consult; but he was not there— I answered a Letter from my Co-Executors of W. N. Boylston, Mrs Alicia Boylston, and Nathaniel Curtis, and sent them the third Bill, of each of the four sets dated 7. 8. 9. and 10. November, on the Brothers Baring and Co. London, each for £500 sterling— Also a private note from Mr Forsyth enquiring whether he might report that the American Commissioners at Ghent never published any part of their Correspondence either with the British Government, or their own—
28. V. Tuesday

Note from Mr Frye— Answered. Mary dined there; though she has not yet shaken off her cough—and Mary-Louisa has yet a remnant of sore throat— Mrs Adams had left with Mr Frye, my private vouchers of property here, which I had left here last Spring— She brought them back the day before yesterday— Mr Frye had some days ago sent to me for an obligation from Johnson Hellen to his sister Mary and for a certificate of Stock in the Bank of Washington in her name— My wife and myself had made fruitless searches for them; I had written to my Son to search for them among the vouchers which I left with him—and his answer informs me that he had searched in vain— Mr Frye wanted this morning, a plat of my land at the Columbian Mills— I looked over the bundle of vouchers, returned the day before yesterday, from Mr Frye’s; and which he had not even opened— I found the obligation from Johnson Hellen to his Sister, but not the Certificate for stock in the Bank of Washington— Nor any of the Deeds of the Columbia Mills— More time must be lost in searching— Mary took her brother’s obligation with her, and left it with Mr Frye— I called at the President’s House, but he was engaged with his cabinet and I left a card— At the Office of the National Intelligencer, but neither Gales nor Seaton was there. At Niles’s Register Office, and found him there. I enquired for Resolutions of the Legislature of the State of Mississippi, for the annexation of Texas to this Union, and for the report of the Committee which proposed the Resolutions— Niles could not tell whether he had published them in the Register or not— But he promised to ascertain; and that if not already published in the Register’s Office they should be— He told me also of a recent Letter of J. C. Calhoun upon the sub-treasury scheme, but could not find it— There is one from Langdon Cheves in the Intelligencer against the sub-treasury—against a Bank of the United-States, and for a Treasury of State Banks. Niles promised also to republish the remainder of Reuben’s Letters to Martin Van Buren, and my two Speeches on the Mississippi election— At Mr Force’s office twice— Waited for him there till he came; and said he had been detained upon the grand-jury— I found in his Library Adair’s History of the Indians—Hubbard—Church and Gibbon, all of which he offered to lend me, and all of which I want to consult— He had also a Memoir of the Life of Sebastian Cabot which he told me was the work of Richard Biddle the present member of the House of Representatives from Pittsburgh— Some notice of it in Mr Cass’s Discourse gave me the first idea that I had of its existence— Force himself a Printer by trade, is one of the most indefatigable antiquarians in the world. He is now Mayor of the City of Washington, and one of the worthiest men living— I have not cultivated his acquaintance so assiduously as I ought to have done— I answered a Letter yesterday received from Mr Robert Gilmor of Baltimore, and it consumed the leisure of the day— It was on
on the important question whether the inscription upon the Washington Monument at Baltimore, commemorating his appointment as Commander in Chief of the American armies of the revolution, should be the 15th. of June 1775 the day of his appointment or the 19th. the date of his Commission— But Mr Gilmer’s Letter has allusions to the whig victories of this day, to which I have responded— Read this evening 50 pages of the Memoirs of Aaron Burr, which brings him to service as a Senator of the United States from New-York, elected Jany 1791.— The book as yet consists almost entirely of private correspondence—
29. V. Wednesday.

Morning visit from James Whitcomb. We had some conversation upon his genealogical enquiries concerning the Whitcomb family, of which I could give him no information, which would be acceptable to him and therefore gave him none— He is chiefly anxious to obtain information about Simon Whitcomb, one of the grantees of the Charter of Charles the 1st. and who he says is mentioned in Hutchinson’s History— But his chief purpose was to shew me a Letter from Jotham Lincoln of Hingham concerning Whitcomb’s project of obtaining for him the office of Collector of the Customs at Boston. Lincoln is very anxious to get the Office, but says he is an opponent of the present administration, and that he can make no compromise of the freedom of his opinions— He says he has always been a warm and steady friend to me through good report and evil report—and seems inclined to write to me on the subject— Mr Whitcomb enquired if he might answer that this would be agreeable to me— I said certainly. He might assure Mr Lincoln of my personal respect and regard; and of my willingness to render him any service in my power— But it would be fitting he should know that there was not perhaps in either house of Congress a member more opposed—not only to the administration, but to all its present measures; not only to the President of the United States, but in a special manner to the Secretary of the Treasury, and his management of the revenue and finances— I had felt it my duty to assail them openly, unequivocally and without reserve, in two Speeches at the late Session of Congress; both of which had been published— It was therefore obvious that in the first place I could not with propriety or self-respect ask any favour of the present Administration, and especially of the Secretary of the Treasury and secondly if I should recommend any person to him for an office, that my recommendation would operate as an effectual exclusion of the candidate whom I should favour— It was known that during the whole of the last Administration I had not been upon speaking terms with the President— Though I had served him more than any other living man ever did—and though I supported his administration, at the hazard of my own political destruction, and effected for him at a moment when
when his own friends were deserting him, what no other member of Congress ever accomplished for him, an unanimous vote of the House of Representatives to support him in his quarrel with France—though I supported him in other very critical periods of his administration, my return from him was, insult, indignity and Slander.— It was not so between me and Mr Van Buren. My relations with him had never been unfriendly; and now I occasionally visited him— But his leading friends in the House of Representatives sided against me in the deadly onset upon me last Winter from the South; and I had in vain tendered the Olive branch to him and them at the late Session, by the office to vote for the measures of relief to the administration if they would give a pledge for the payment of the fourth instalment of the deposits on the 1st. of January 1839. by appropriating the money for it— Mr Whitcomb said he believed there must and would be soon a change in the policy of the administration; though he did hear that there had been since the close of the late Session, and still continued an active correspondence between J. C. Calhoun and President Van Buren— He said he had taken the Liberty to say, and to write to Mr Dickerson, the only member of the Cabinet with whom he had a personal acquaintance, that unless the Administration should give more countenance to the old republican party in Massachusetts, they would lose all their friends there— However that may be, there is not a symptom of a change in the policy of the administration— I gave the last sitting to Mrs Towle for my Portrait, which she has not yet quite finished— A strong but not a pleasing likeness— Call at the National Intelligencer Office.— Mr Gales gave me for perusal the manuscript of the Speech of Arphaxed Loomis on the Mississippi election— Mr J. P. Todd Mrs Madison’s son came this afternoon, and left with me a collection of Manuscript Letters from the late Mr Madison upon Constitutional questions— I have taken from the Congress Library and am looking into M’Culloch’s Edition of Smith’s Wealth of Nations—and this evening I continued reading the Memoirs of A. Burr—till the time of the death of his wife 31. March 1794.— A few of her Letters are given— But none that discover much character— His correspondence with his daughter begins in the 9th. year of her age, and the Letters from him are frequent— He was extremely anxious about her education, and had her taught Greek, Latin—French, Music, and dancing, and arithmetic and elegant manners, but no religion or morals— She reads Lucian, Homer and Terence, but not the Bible.
30. IV:15 Thursday

I am endeavouring to finish the biographical sketch of my father for my father but my subject swells as I proceed, and here is the Session of Congress again close at hand. Mr G. W. Cherry was here again this morning, and I had a long conversation with him upon his project of Colonization— He is one of the most benevolent
benevolent visionaries, of that fraudulent charitable institution the Colonization Society— His plan is to raise a fund for purchasing a number of Slaves, and locating them in small villages where they may in a given time purchase their freedom by their own labour— I freely gave my opinion to Mr Cherry that the whole colonization project was an abortion— That as a system of eventual emancipation of the Slaves of this Country, it was not only impracticable, but demonstrated to be so— That as a scheme for relieving the Slave States of free Negroes, its moral aspect was not comely, and it was equally impracticable. I held this opinion when the existence of the Colonization Society was first made known to me in September 1817. every day’s experience had confirmed me in it, from that time to this— I have never taken any part against the colonization Society— But I never joined it—never attended any of its meetings, and never believed in its usefulness— I observed that by the very last accounts published by the Society itself, it appeared that even now, after twenty years of continual migration to the settlements it appeared they were starving for want of bread; with a fertile soil, and a Latitude close upon the equator— And the cause assigned of it is that the colonists waste their time in idleness and will not work— Mr Cherry had little to say in reply to this, but he took my remarks in kindness, and thanked me for the attention that I had given to his plan in the African Repository, which I returned to him.— I called at the Department of State and enquired of Mr Forsyth, if there was upon its files a Letter from Moses Austin the first settler from the United States in Texas to me, written between 1819 and 1822— He said he would have search made, and let me know— I spoke of the note received from him last Monday, and of my answer. He said that in the correspondence with the Mexican Government, concerning the improper publication of Mr Gorostiza, they had alleged that the American Commissioners at Ghent, had made some such publication— He thought it was in consequence of something said in debate by Mr Clay at the late Session of Congress— I called at the Treasury Department, but Mr Woodbury was with the President— At the Congress Library and took out the trial of Captain Preston and the Soldiers for the Boston Massacre of 5. March 1770. Towards Evening I visited Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith, and afterwards finished reading the first Volume of the Memoir of Burr— It brings him down to the Marriage of his daughter to Joseph Alston of South-Carolina in 1801—and to that singularly contested election of that year between Thomas Jefferson and him— That is told in the second Volume.

Day. We have had the finest three months of Autumn, from the 2d. of September when I arrived here to this Summer’s day, that I ever experienced— My rising average hour about 4:30— That of retirement 9:30 P.M— My health uncommonly good—my mind anxious but cheerful— My occupations incessant and overburthened.— My achievement lamentably small.— Relief from crazing care and bitter anguish, and forebodings of approaching to meet which my reliance is only on a merciful superintending Providence.
